Yeah, I know. We've had our hearts broken so many times. I remember when I used to post regularly in the NYTimes gay rights forum, and we were all so excited about our efforts to elect Al Gore. We thought, well we have been losing on so many fronts with all the DOMA laws being passed by the states, but our hope lies in Al Gore! We gay and bi and trans folks gave him our hearts, thought we had a victory, and then saw it snatched away. Some people said, "No more with politics! It's just corrupt, and the Republicans will steal any victory we get." Others of us were dismayed, but we gradually got over the blow. Then came the war, and we had to mobilize against that. Meanwhile, we began to have some victories, in the courts especially. We had Lawrence v. Texas, which was followed by the court ruling in Massachusetts, where we won marriage rights. 
 
 Then came the election of 2004, and again we got our hopes up, only to have them dashed again in November. The gloomy morning after John Kerry's loss seemed to many of us to be the low moment of modern American politics. But we picked ourselves up yet again and went forward. There would be more victories and more losses for our movement for equality. 
 
 Now here it is four years later. Bush is really leaving this time. And we have a new opportunity for a new romance with a new leader. Have we been disappointed too many times to love again? 
 
 It's clear to me that electing a President will not win us equal rights and fair treatment under the law and in the society. But it can certainly help, especially if the President uses the bully pulpit to support equality. Barack Obama, like Hillary Clinton who lost, has never supported fully equal marriage rights. But there is the possibility, which he has left open. 
 
 It strikes me that for many reasons, Barack Obama will be a far better President than John McCain. I think it's time we give our hearts, and our hands, to Barack Obama, not because he will be our savior, but because he can as President help out our movement to win full equality and fair treatment for lgbt people. He won't win those for us, but it will be helpful for us to have a President who supports something close to equality.
